notes:
1. Concepts

Shear Force Diagrams (SFD) and Bending Moment Diagrams (BMD) are graphical representations of the internal shear force ($V$) and bending moment ($M$) at all points along the length of a beam.

  • Shear Force ($V$): The sum of all vertical forces acting on the beam to the left (or right) of a section. It tends to slide adjacent layers of the beam vertically.
  • Bending Moment ($M$): The sum of all moments (including those from forces) acting on the beam to the left (or right) of a section. It tends to bend the beam.

2. Sign Convention

The standard sign convention for internal forces is:

  • Positive Shear (+V): Upward on the left face, downward on the right face.
  • Positive Moment (+M): Compresses the top fibers and elongates the bottom fibers (makes the beam 'smile').

3. Differential Relationships

There are fundamental mathematical relationships between the distributed load ($w(x)$), shear ($V(x)$), and moment ($M(x)$):

  • The slope of the shear diagram is equal to the negative of the distributed load intensity. $$ \frac{dV}{dx} = -w(x) $$ So, the change in shear between two points is the area under the load curve (negative). $$ \Delta V = -\int w(x) dx $$
  • The slope of the moment diagram is equal to the shear force. $$ \frac{dM}{dx} = V(x) $$ So, the change in moment between two points is the area under the shear curve. $$ \Delta M = \int V(x) dx $$

Key Insight: Maximum and minimum moments occur where the shear force is zero (since $dM/dx = V = 0$).

solvedExamples.question: If the shear force diagram for a beam is a horizontal line with a constant positive value, what is the shape of the bending moment diagram?

options.text: A straight line with a positive slope.
A straight line with a negative slope.

solvedExamples.explanation: The slope of the moment diagram is equal to the shear force ($dM/dx = V$). If V is a positive constant, then the slope of M is a positive constant, which describes a straight line sloping upwards.

solvedExamples.question: The change in bending moment between two points on a beam is equal to:

options.text: The area under the load diagram between those points.
The area under the shear diagram between those points.
The difference in shear force between those points.
The slope of the shear diagram.

solvedExamples.explanation: According to the integral relationship $\Delta M = \int V(x) dx$, the change in moment is geometrically represented by the area under the shear force diagram.
